ARTICLE II. - STREETS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Possession of open containers of alcoholic beverages prohibited, § 6-5. 
 
Sec. 42-36. - Use of rights-of-way. 
(a)	Consent required. Pursuant to the police power of the city, the city council hereby determines, in the interest of the health, safety and welfare of its citizens, that the use of any city right-of-way, including appendages thereto, and the use of any public lands under the authority of the city council, except for their intended purpose, without prior written consent of the city shall be prohibited, except as necessary for the maintenance responsibilities set forth in section 30-53(b) of this code. 
(b)	Commercial use. The prohibition set out in subsection (a) of this section includes any commercial use, including but not limited to the sale of and display for sale of any merchandise, the servicing or repair of any vehicles except the rendering of emergency service, the storage or parking of vehicles and the display of advertising of any sort. 
(c)	Recreational use. Unless specifically designed for such purpose, the prohibition set out in subsection (a) of this section shall also include camping, sleeping, parking (except for emergency reasons), and any other use that would tend to obstruct traffic along the city rights-of-way, including appendages thereto, and to any other public lands under the authority of the city council, without prior written approval by the city. 
(d)	Penalty. Violations of this section are punishable as provided in section 1-15. 
(Ord. No. 94-30, § I, 4-6-94; Ord. No. 03-11, § 2, 4-20-11; Ord. No. 03-12, § II, 8-1-12)  
Secs. 42-37—42-54. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SPECIAL EVENTS 
 
Sec. 42-55. - Definitions. 
The following terms, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section: 
Advertise means the act of publicly announcing or calling public attention to a person, thing, place or event and shall include, but not be limited to, the distribution of handbills or mass mailings, the use of outdoor advertising and announcements by radio, television or newspaper. 
Bicycle path means a public way intended primarily for bicyclists, at the side of a street or in or through a public park or other public property. 
Discrimination means any difference in the treatment or favor extended to a natural person, including exclusion or segregation because of race, color, religion, national origin, ancestry or sex. 
Outdoor assembly permit (also referred to herein as permit) means a permit as required by this article. 
Outdoor public assembly (also referred to herein as assembly or public assembly) means any ceremony, circus, show, exhibition, concert, pageant, rally, demonstration or parade which is held in or on any street, sidewalk, any public property or park. 
Parade means any procession, march or assembly wherein the participants travel by foot, vehicle or otherwise in or upon any street, or public parking facility within the city. 
Parks means those areas designed on the City Charter Park and Waterfront Property Map on file with the clerk of city council and incorporated by reference in the City Charter. 
Public issue or political speech or conduct means that noncommercial expression of ideas of public concern related to government, religion, economics, society, culture and matters of a similar nature as determined by the courts of controlling jurisdiction be entitled to the greatest protection of the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. 
Public property means any property generally open to the public owned by the United States, the county, or the state and any property owned by the city other than a street, a park or a sidewalk. 
Sidewalk means any area or way set aside or open to the general public for purposes of pedestrian traffic, whether or not it is paved. 
Street means any place or way set aside or open to the general public for purposes of vehicular traffic, including any curb or shoulder, parkway, right-of-way or median strip thereof. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 1, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-56. - Activities exempt from this article. 
This article shall not apply to: 
(1)	Funeral processions. 
(2)	Lawful picketing or other orderly processions on the sidewalks that do not constitute loitering. 
(3)	A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 2, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-57. - Compliance by permittee with regulations. 
A permittee hereunder shall comply with all permit directions and conditions, and with all applicable laws and ordinances. The assembly chairperson or other person heading or leading such assembly shall carry the permit upon his person during the conduct of the assembly and shall display the permit upon demand to any officer of the Volusia County Sheriff's Office. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 3, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-58. - Regulations of parking on parade route. 
The Volusia County Sheriff or his designee shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The Volusia County Sheriff shall cause signs to be posted to such effect and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 4, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-59. - Required. 
(a)	No person shall conduct a parade or outdoor public assembly without obtaining a permit in accordance with this article. 
(b)	No person shall knowingly participate in a parade or public assembly on the city streets or in a city park or other public property for which a permit has not been granted. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 5, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-60. - Application. 
(a)	Any person seeking the issuance of an outdoor public assembly permit for the use of a park or for a parade shall file an application therefor with city manager or designee. 
(b)	The application shall be filed at least 30 days prior to the time on which the parade or public assembly is to be held. An application for a public assembly permit for a parade shall not be filed more than 180 days prior to the event. 
(c)	Where an applicant/intends to engage in public issue speech or conduct and the parade has been planned or scheduled by the applicant for less than 30 days prior to the time on which the public assembly is to be held, the application shall be filed at least five working days prior to the event. If, however, an application is filed in a shorter time frame due to the exigency of the nature of the issue, the city shall process such an application. 
(d)	The application shall be signed by the applicant under oath, and shall indicate whether the applicant intends to engage in public issue speech. 
(e)	Applications shall be on forms provided by the city manager or his designee and shall set forth the following information and such other information as from time to time may be required in order to allow the city manager to evaluate the application for compliance with this article: 
(1)	The name, place of residence, mailing address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct the assembly. 
(2)	If the assembly is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
(3)	The date when the assembly is to be conducted. 
(4)	The type of assembly, including a description of the activities which will occur during the event. 
(5)	The hours when such assembly will start and terminate. 
(6)	A description of any and all recording equipment, sound-amplification equipment, banners, signs or other attention-getting devices, including dimensions of and description of materials of any such banners, signs or devices which will be utilized in connection with the assembly. 
(7)	The approximate number of participants, including spectators, which can be reasonably anticipated. 
(8)	If the assembly is designed to be held by, on behalf of or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the city manager a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the assembly, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
(9)	The exact location of the assembly and, if the assembly is a parade, the location by streets of any marshaling area or areas for such parade. 
(10)	A designation of any public facilities or equipment proposed to be utilized. 
(11)	If the application is for a parade, the application shall also contain the following information: 
a.	The time at which units of the parade will begin to arrive at the marshaling area or areas, and the times at which all such units will be disbursed therefrom. 
b.	The starting time of the parade and the approximate length of time that the parade will last. 
c.	The route to be traveled, including the starting and ending points. 
d.	The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade and the type of animals and description of the vehicles. 
e.	A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets or sidewalks to be used. 
(12)	Whether alcoholic beverages will be sold or consumed at the event. 
(13)	A statement that the purpose of the assembly and the expected conduct of the participants will conform to all requirements of law, and all ordinances of the county and the city. 
(14)	A statement whether the assembly is for the purpose of public issue or political speech or conduct and if so, the specific purpose of the assembly and a general description of the proposed public issue or political speech or conduct. 
(15)	If the assembly is for the purpose of public issue or political speech or conduct, the amount of funds available to pay the cost of city services and whether a claim of indigence is made on behalf of the applicant or the person on whose behalf the application is made and whether the applicant requests a waiver of fees, costs and insurance requirements. 
(16)	The identity of the individual or entity which will be responsible for payment of city services. 
(17)	Such parade or public assembly is not for the primary purpose of advertising any product, goods or event that is primarily for private profit, and the parade itself is not primarily for profit. The prohibition against advertising any product, goods or event shall not apply to signs identifying organizations or sponsors furnishing or sponsoring exhibits or structures used in the parade. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 6, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-61. - Standards for issuance. 
(a)	The city manager or his designee shall issue a permit as provided for under this division [article] when, from a consideration of the application and from other information as may otherwise be obtained, it appears that: 
(1)	The conduct of the assembly will not unduly disturb the safe and orderly movement of other pedestrian or vehicular traffic contiguous to the route or location of the assembly. 
{2)	The concentration of persons, animals and/or vehicles at the assembly will not interfere unduly with proper fire and law enforcement protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to the assembly area or other areas of the city. 
(3)	Adequate sanitation and other required health facilities are or will be made available in or adjacent to the assembly area and, if applicable, the marshaling area or areas. 
(4)	There are reasonable adequate parking places near the site of the assembly and, if applicable, marshaling area or areas, to accommodate the approximate number of vehicles reasonably expected to be driven to the assembly. 
(5)	The applicant has secured the law enforcement and other City services, if any, required under section 42-64 or has obtained a waiver of fees pursuant to subsection 42-62(c). 
(6)	If the assembly is a parade, such parade is not to be held for the primary purpose of advertising any product or goods or is not primarily for profit; provided, however, the prohibition against advertising any product, goods or event shall not apply to signs identifying organizations or sponsors furnishing or sponsoring exhibits or structures used in the conduct of the assembly. 
(7)	No outdoor public assembly permit application for the same time and location has been received which has been or will be granted. 
(8)	No outdoor public assembly permit application for the same time but in another location has been or will be granted where the law enforcement resources required for that prior public assembly are so great that, in combination with the subsequent proposed application, the resulting deployment of law enforcement services would have an immediate and adverse effect upon the welfare and safety of persons and property. 
(9)	No event is scheduled elsewhere in the city where the law enforcement or other city resources required for that event are so great that the deployment of law enforcement or other city services for the proposed assembly would have an immediate and adverse effect upon the welfare and safety of persons and property. 
(10)	If alcoholic beverages are to be sold or served, proper permits must have been or will be obtained. Approval of a permit under this division [article] shall not eliminate the necessity for any other approvals for such sale or dispensation of alcoholic beverages as required by law or ordinance. 
(11)	Participants in the assembly shall not use sticks, lumber, metal poles or other objects to display signs or banners at the public assembly. 
(12)	Participants in the assembly will not violate the law in connection with the assembly. 
(13)	The content of signs, banners or speech, whether written or oral, except to the extent that such content constitutes a violation of any applicable law or ordinance, will not be considered by the city manager in acting upon the application. 
(b)	No permit shall be granted that allows for the erection or placement of any structure whether permanent or temporary, on a city street, sidewalk, or right-of-way unless advance approval for the erection or placement of the structure is obtained from the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 7, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-62. - Permit fees, costs; waiver. 
(a)	Where an outdoor public assembly permit is requested, a nonrefundable fee of $40.00 to cover the administrative costs of processing the permit shall be paid to the city by the person applying for the permit at the time of filing of the application. 
(b)	If the application is for the use of city property or if city services shall be required for the assembly, the applicant shall pay for the charges in accordance with a schedule of fees approved by the mayor and city council prior to the issuance of the permit; provided, if the applicant is indigent and is engaged in public issue speech or conduct within the meaning of section 42-55 the applicant shall not be required to pay any fee described in this section. 
(c)	If the applicant is claiming indigency and is applying for an outdoor public assembly permit for the purpose of public issue speech or conduct the applicant shall apply to the mayor and city council stating that the applicant wishes a waiver of a portion or all of the costs of processing the permits and other City services. The city manager or the designee thereof, or the city attorney or the designee thereof, shall determine if the applicant fulfills the public issue and indigency requirement in order to receive a waiver of costs of the processing fee and city services. 
(d)	An applicant, who is indigent and intends to engage in public issue speech or conduct, shall not be required to meet the requirements of section 42-63. 
(e)	An applicant is indigent within the meaning of this section when the applicant is unable to pay the cost of city services required for a public assembly after the payment of basic expenses necessary for the continued operation and existence of the organization including, but not necessarily limited to, rent and utilities. As proof of such indigency, the applicant shall supply an affidavit of indigency together with such other information as is reasonably required in support thereof. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 8, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-63. - Financial responsibility. 
(a)	The applicant for an outdoor public assembly permit for a parade and any other person on whose behalf the application is made, by filing the application, does represent, stipulate, contract and agree to indemnify, save and hold harmless, and defend the city and all of its officers and employees, including employees of the County of Volusia who provide contractual law enforcement services for the city from all suits, actions, damages, loss, liability and claims of any character, name or description brought for, or on account of, any injuries or damages received or sustained by any person or property arising out of the applicant's negligence, or negligence of its officers, agents, representatives, guests, employees, invitees or persons contracting with the applicant, whether it be sole negligence or joint negligence with others in connection with performance under the public assembly permit or by or on account of any act or omission, neglect or wrongdoing of the applicant, its officers, agents, representatives, guests, employees, invitees or persons contracting with the applicant. 
(b)	In addition to the requirements of subsection (a), no outdoor public assembly permit shall be issued for parades unless the applicant shall obtain and maintain for any and all activities associated with the parade, not limited to the staging of the parade, parade route, and disbanding of the parade, such commercial general liability insurance as shall provide coverage for the applicant for bodily injury and personal injury, including accidental death, as well as from claims for property damage which may arise from operations under the permit, whether such operations be by the applicant or by any of its agents, representatives, guests, employees, invitees or anyone contracting with the applicant or by anyone directly or indirectly employed by any of them, except to the extent that claim arises from the negligent or wrongful conduct of the city or its employees. An occurrence type policy is preferred. The city shall be named as a certificate holder and as an additional insured on the policy. The policy limits of insurance shall not be less than $500,000.00 combined single limit each occurrence for bodily injury and property damage. 
(c)	At the time of the application for an outdoor public assembly permit for a parade, satisfactory proof that the insurance required by subsection (b) has been obtained shall be presented to the city manager or his designee. The requirement for satisfactory proof may be complied with either by depositing the insurance policy itself or by furnishing a certificate of insurance meeting the following specifications to the city manager: 
(1)	The insurance policy issued shall be listed and for each policy, the type of insurance, policy number, expiration date and limits of liability shall be shown. 
(2)	The certificate shall designate the city as certificate holder and as an additional insured and shall contain a statement to the effect that the policies listed are in force and that in the event of cancellation or any material change in a policy affecting the certificate holder at least ten days prior written notice shall be given to the certificate holder. 
(3)	Below the schedule of insurance in force, the certificate shall include a statement substantially as follows: "The comprehensive general liability policy listed above includes coverage of designated premises and coverage for contractual liability in compliance with the provisions of Section 42-63 of the DeBary City Code, for a parade to be held on ____________ / ____________ / ____________ , 19 ____________ ." 
(4)	The certificate of insurance shall be signed by an authorized agent of the issuing company or companies and shall have attached a copy of a power of attorney evidencing the agent's authority. 
(d)	If motor vehicles are to be included, evidence of public liability insurance with the same limits on vehicles may be accepted in lieu of the insurance required in subsections (b) and (c). 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 9, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-64. - Procedures for consideration. 
Upon receipt of a filed application, the city manager or his designee shall determine the extent to which law enforcement and other city services will be necessary for the assembly for the purposes of traffic control and public safety. This determination shall be based upon the size, location, duration, time and date of the event, the expected sale of alcoholic beverages, the number of streets and intersections to be blocked and the need to detour or preempt ordinary citizen travel and use of the streets or sidewalks. If possible without disruption of ordinary city services or compromise to public safety, the event will be policed by regularly scheduled on-duty personnel. If additional city services for the assembly are deemed necessary, the applicant for the permit shall be so informed. The applicant shall have the duty to secure law enforcement and other city services deemed necessary at the sole expense of the applicant, who shall prepay or guarantee to prepay the expense of such protection unless a waiver of fees and costs has been granted pursuant to section 42-62, at the discretion of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 10, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-65. - Notice of denial. 
The city manager or designee shall act promptly upon a timely filed application for a permit. If the application is denied, the applicant shall be notified by certified mail, return receipt requested, of the action, stating the reason for the denial at least 48 hours prior to the event. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 11, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-66. - Public issue speech—Procedure. 
(a)	If a proposed parade or event involves a public issue speech, the city manager shall within seven calendar days of the filing date of the application, or by the date requested for the parade, or event, whichever comes first, either: 
(1)	Issue the public assembly permit and notify the applicant and appropriate city departments; 
(2)	Issue an alternative permit and notify the applicant and appropriate city departments; or 
(3)	Refuse to issue the permit and notify the applicant of the refusal. 
(b)	A refusal to issue the permit shall be based on the standards stated in section 42-61. 
(c)	The city manager shall, after consulting with the appropriate city departments, and after considering the fee schedule approved by city council, notify the applicant of an estimate of the dollar amount city services will cost. 
(d)	The notification required by subsection (a)(3) shall occur within three days of the filing date of the application, but no later than the scheduled date of the parade. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 12, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-67. - Public issue speech—Judicial review. 
(a)	If an application for a permit for engaging in an event, parade or demonstration conducted for the purpose of public issue speech or conduct is denied or if an alternative permit for such speech is tendered by the city and rejected by an applicant or applicants, the city shall either issue the requested permit or promptly initiate judicial proceedings for a determination of the lawfulness of the denial of the permit or, where an alternative permit has been rejected, the lawfulness of the tender of the alternative permit. Failure to notify the city within five days of the acceptance or rejection of the alternative permit shall be deemed a withdrawal of the permit application. 
(b)	If the issue for judicial determination described in subsection (a) is not heard and decided on the merits by a court of competent jurisdiction within ten days from the date that the action is filed or by the date for which the permit is requested, whichever comes first, the requested permit shall be deemed issued. 
(c)	The applicant may, but shall not be required to, comply with section 42-69 prior to judicial proceedings being instituted or concluded. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 13, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-68. - Alternative permits. 
(a)	Where an application for permit is denied by the city manager in the interest of traffic control and/or public safety, the city manager may authorize the conduct of the assembly on a date, at a time, or over a route or in a location different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternative permit shall within five days after notice of authorization accept or reject such alternative permit. Failure of the applicant to accept or reject the alternative permit within these five days shall be deemed to be a withdrawal of the permit application. In considering an alternative permit, the city manager shall consider the express purpose and the intent of the applicant's initial request and shall not act to deny the applicant an appropriate forum for the event through the alternative permit. An alternative permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of, a permit under this division [article]. 
(b)	In the event the mayor and city council grant a partial waiver of fees and costs pursuant to subsection 42-62(c), the clerk shall notify the applicant by certified mail, return receipt requested, that payment of any fees must be paid or payment guaranteed prior to the issuance of the permit. The mayor and city council shall instruct the city manager to recommend to the applicant an alternative permit whereby the event may be held without payment of any unwaived fees or costs. In recommending the alternative permit the purpose of the event shall be considered in order to provide the applicant with an appropriate forum. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 14, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-69. - Appeal procedure. 
(a)	Any applicant shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade or public assembly permit to the mayor and city council. The denied applicant shall make the appeal within five days after receipt of the denial by filing a written notice with the city manager and city clerk. The mayor and city council shall act upon the appeal at the next scheduled meeting following receipt of the notice of appeal. 
(b)	In the event that the mayor and city council reject an applicant's appeal, the applicant may file a petition for writ of certiorari to the circuit court. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 15, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-70. - Notice to city officials. 
Immediately upon the issuance of a permit, the city manager or his designee, shall send a copy thereof to each of the following: 
(1)	Mayor. 
(2)	City clerk. 
(3)	Volusia County Transportation Engineer. 
(4)	Volusia County Sheriff. 
(5)	Volusia County Chief of the Fire Department. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 16, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-71. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)	The city manager or his designee shall have the authority to revoke a permit for a parade issued under this division [article] instantly upon violation of any one or more of the conditions or standards for issuance as herein set forth or when a public emergency arises where the law enforcement resources are required for that emergency are so great that deployment of law enforcement services for the assembly would have an immediate and adverse effect upon the welfare and safety of persons or property. 
(b)	Where public issue speech or conduct is involved, the revocation of a permit shall be treated for all purposes as a denial of a permit under section 42-67, and all provisions of such section shall apply thereto. Notice of revocation hereunder shall be given to the permittee by the most practicable and expeditious means available under the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 17, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-72. - Parks. 
No additional permit must be obtained for a public assembly in a park other than a permit pursuant to this division [article]. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 18, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-73. - Contents of permit. 
Each parade or public assembly permit shall state the following information: 
(1)	Starting and approximate ending time; 
(2)	Minimum speed of parade units; 
(3)	Maximum speed of parade units; 
(4)	Maximum interval of space to be maintained between parade units; 
(5)	The portions of the streets that may be occupied by the parade or public assembly; 
(6)	The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof; and 
(7)	Such other information as the city manager shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 19, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-74. - Public conduct during assemblies. 
(a)	Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any duly licensed assembly, or with any person, vehicle, or animal participating or used in such assembly. 
(b)	Driving through parades. No driver of any vehicle, unless specifically permitted by an officer of the Volusia County Sheriff's Department, shall drive between the vehicles of persons comprising a duly licensed parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(c)	Parking on parade route or in area near assembly. The Volusia County Sheriff shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a parade or an area needed for the safe and efficient flow of traffic to or from an assembly. The Volusia County Sheriff shall post signs to such effect and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 20, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-75. - Discrimination prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any permittee, or any agent or employee of the permitee, either directly or indirectly: 
(1)	To discriminate against any natural person by refusing, withholding, or denying to such person any of the services, advantages, facilities or privileges offered or available to any other person attending the assembly, or by setting different rates or charges therefor, or by placing or attempting to place any such natural person in a separate and segregated section or area at the assembly. 
(2)	To publish, circulate, display, post or mail any written or printed communication or notice to the effect that any of the services, advantages, facilities or privileges of the assembly will be refused, withheld or denied to any natural person on account of the person's race, color, religion, national origin, ancestry, or sex, or that the person's attendance and presence at the assembly is unwelcome or objectionable, or that the person will be prohibited from mingling with other persons at the assembly because of the person's race, color, religion, national origin, ancestry or sex. 
(3)	To aid, abet, incite or coerce the doing of any act declared herein to be unlawful, or to prevent or attempt to prevent any person from complying with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 21, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 42-76. - Penalties. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to stage, present, or conduct any assembly or block party without first having obtained permits therefor as herein provided. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to participate in an assembly or block party for which permits have not been granted. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of or responsible for the conduct of a duly licensed assembly or block party to knowingly fail to comply with any condition of a permit. 
(d)	Any person violating the provisions of any section of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished by fine not to exceed $500.00 or imprisonment of not more than 60 days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, § 22, 11-6-96)  
Chapter 46 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes:
